data.text: Contents
Purpose
To promote best practice in the diagnosis and treatment of headaches following the NICE guidelines.
To ensure that all children cared for by Mid Essex Hospital are treated using best practice.
To ensure that each child is listened to and their rights respected.
To evaluate the child who presents with headache and consider the need for further treatment or referral.
Definitions
Headache disorders have 2 main classifications, these are primary and secondary type.
2.1.2 Primary Headaches
These are the most common and are categorised as:
Tension-type headache
Migraine
Cluster headache
2.1.3 Secondary Headaches
These are caused by underlying disorders such as:
Medication overuse
Infection
Raised intracranial pressure
Sinusitis
Roles and responsibilities

The Specialist Nurse for Guidelines and Audit is responsible for ensuring clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guideline within the directorate.
The Head of Nursing and Quality for Children and Young People and paediatric wards' managers are responsible for ensuring paediatric staff are aware of the guideline and implement it.
The Paediatric Clinical Lead Consultant is responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical setting.
All paediatric staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this guideline.
Assessment
Children who present with headaches who have any of the following features require a consideration for further investigation and or referral to a specialist:
Worsening headache with fever
Sudden onset with maximum intensity reached within 5 minutes
New-onset neurological deficit
New-onset cognitive dysfunction
Change in personality
Impaired level of consciousness
Recent head trauma (within 3 months)
Headaches triggered by coughing, sneezing or breathing through a blocked nose
Headaches triggered by exercise
Orthostatic headache (triggered by changes in posture)
Substantial changes in characteristics of headaches
Compromised immunity
History of malignancy
History of brain malignancy or metastasise brain malignancy
Vomiting without obvious cause

Consider a headache diary for a minimum of 8 weeks asking the patient or family to record frequency, duration, severity of the headaches and any associated symptoms. Ask them to also note any medication used to relieve the headache. If appropriate ask them to note the relationship between headaches and the menstruation cycle. Patients can also consider using online headache diaries from online websites such as Migraine Trust or Migraine Action. User friendly apps are also available on these websites.
Diagnosis
Tension type headaches
Table 1- Diagnosis of tension-type headache, migraine and cluster headache

table_items.text: Unilateral (around the eye, above the eye and along the
Pulsating (throbbing or banging in young people aged 12–17 years)
Variable (can be sharp, boring, burning, throbbing or tightening)
Not aggravated by routine activities of daily living
Aggravated by, or causes avoidance of, routine activities of daily living

Unusual sensitivity to light and/or sound or nausea and/or vomiting Aura Symptoms can occur with or without headache and: are fully reversible  develop over at least 5 minutes last 5−60 minutes. Typical aura symptoms include visual symptoms such as flickering lights, spots or lines and/or partial loss of vision; sensory symptoms such as numbness and/or pins and needles; and/or speech disturbance.
On the same side as the headache: red and/or watery eye  nasal congestion and/or runny nose swollen eyelid  forehead and facial sweating constricted pupil and/or drooping eyelid
4–72 hours in adults 1–72 hours in young people aged 12–17 years
≥ 15 days per month for more than 3 months
≥ 15 days per month for more than 3 months
1 every other day to 8 per day3, with remission4 > 1 month
1 every other day to 8 per day3, with a continuous remission4 <1 month in a 12-month period

data.text: Migraine aura
Aura should be suspected in people with neurological symptoms that are fully reversible and develop gradually and last for between 5 and  minutes.
5.2.1 Diagnosis of migraine with aura patients with or without headache that meet one or more of the typical symptoms which are:
Visual symptoms that may be positive e.g. flickering lights, spots or lines and or negative e.g. partial loss of vision.
Sensory symptoms that may be positive e.g. pins and needles or negative e.g. numbness
Speech disturbance

5.2.2 Further investigation and referral may be considered in children who present with atypical symptoms such as motor weakness or double vision or visual disturbance affecting one eye or poor balance or decreased level of consciousness.
Menstrual related Headaches

These types of headaches should be suspected in girls whose migraine occurs between 2 days before and 3 days after the start of the menstrual cycle in at least 2 out of 3 cycles. Diagnosis of this is best done using a headache diary.
Medication overuse

Be aware of children whose headaches develop or worsen while they are taking the following drugs for 3 or more months. Triptans, opioids, ergots or combination analgesic medications on  days per month or Paracetamol, aspirin or and NSAID, either alone or in combination on  days per month or more. It is worth considering two per week rule to be advised in the clinic to children with headaches to prevent medication overuse and this has to be documented within the clinical notes as part of the NICE guidelines. The two per week rule means not to take more than 2 doses of the same medication per week.
Management
Using a headache diary to record frequency, duration and severity of headaches. Use of the diary should also monitor effectiveness of interventions and form a basis for discussion.
Do not refer people diagnosed with tension-type headache, migraine, cluster headache or medication overuse headache for neuroimaging solely for reassurance.
Written and oral information about headache disorders including information about support organisations much be given to families and young people. (Migraine Trust and Migraine Action)
Consider paracetamol, and /or NSAID for tension type headaches. Do not offer opioids for the acute treatment of tension type headaches.

Consider nasal Triptan for children over  years. Children under 12 years should use NSAIDS and paracetamol. Consider an anti-emetic in addition to other acute treatment of migraine even if nausea and vomiting are not present.
Triptan is not normally recommended if you are suspecting Migraine with neurological features like hemiplegic migraine or basilar migraine.
Training requirements
All medical and nursing staff are to ensure that their knowledge, competencies and skills are up to date in order to complete their portfolio and appraisal.
During induction all staff will receive instruction on current policies and guidelines and how to access them.
Guideline Management

7.3.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Monitoring and audit

table_items.text: Aspect of compliance or effectiveness being monitored
Individual department responsible for the monitoring
Group / Committee / forum which will receive the findings/monitoring report
Committee / individual responsible for ensuring the actions are completed
Appropriate action not taken as highlighted via DATIX reporting system
Risk Management Group/ Patient Safety Group

data.text: Where a Patient's notes have demonstrated that the appropriate action has not been taken then a ‘DATIX' form is to be completed. This will highlight further staff training needs.
A quarterly DATIX audit will be examined by the Lead Nurse and the clinical director and risk lead for CYP

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy, the Women's and Children's Directorate annual audit work plan and the NHSLA/CNST requirements. The Audit Lead in liaison with the Risk Management Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Risk Management Group and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Paediatric Practice Steering Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the relevant Paediatric staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
This Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 1)
References

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2015) Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management. Clinical Guideline (CG 150) London: NICE Available from: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg150
National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2013) Headaches in over 12s. Quality Standard (QS 42) London: NICE
